awd_titl_txt: Coastal SEES (Track 2), Collaborative: Improving Chesapeake Bay water quality by creating sustainable coastal watersheds
awd_abstract_narration:
Coastal water quality is controlled by land uses in the surrounding watershed and is declining in many coastal regions. The land that drains toward estuaries contributes pollutants (primarily nitrogen, phosphorus, and sediment) from fertilized lawns, septic systems, and sewage treatment plants. Water quality in the Choptank River and estuary, which flow into the Chesapeake Bay, is declining because of runoff from agriculture, but sewage disposal is also a contributing source of nutrients.  Better management of cultivated and residential land is required to improve water quality, and many best management practices are employed to reduce pollutants. Although we know a great deal about how some individual Best Management Practices remove nutrients and other pollutants, best management practices have never been tested at the watershed scale to determine if they actually improve receiving water quality. This research will study the people and land management of four Choptank watersheds. The researchers will determine the attitudes towards adoption of best management practices, mechanisms of pollutant reduction in specific best management practices, and landscape water quality as a result of widespread implementation. 

Many government programs are committed to encouraging best management practices to improve water quality, but there is uncertainty whether commonly applied best management practices significantly reduce pollutant fluxes from watersheds to estuaries. The Choptank study will provide an important test of the effectiveness of best management practices at the watershed scale, the results of which can potentially be applied elsewhere. This project will involve education of residents, farmers, the media, and government officials, and will also involve scouts and 4-H organizations. The research has the potential to identify effective best management practices and to create sustainable, agricultural watersheds in the coastal zone.

por.por_cntn:
Chesapeake Bay has a long history of anthropogenic nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) inputs resulting in degraded water quality. The primary sources of N and P inputs are agricultural diffuse sources in rural watersheds and wastewater point sources in urbanized watersheds. Wastewater treatment plants are undergoing upgrades to tertiary treatment (removal of N and P), whereas control of agricultural diffuse sources is encouraged by government agencies via adoption of agricultural best management practices (BMPs). Unlike point sources, agricultural diffuse sources are typically not monitored, and estimated reductions are based on previous field trials, with few observations at the watershed scale. While large reductions in sewage N and P have been documented for many wastewater plants with tertiary treatment, empirical observations of agricultural diffuse sources of N and P in watersheds usually show mixed patterns of degradation, no change, and improvements, despite generally favorable model predictions. This has led to questions of whether agricultural BMPs are as efficient as the assumptions used in current models or whether a sufficient number of BMPs have been installed.

In 2013 we began an empirical test of the effects of agricultural BMPs at the watershed scale funded by the National Science Foundation. We worked in four small (8-16 km2) watersheds in the Choptank Basin on the Delmarva Peninsula. The watersheds had been monitored at their outlets for water discharge and baseflow chemistry since 2003, providing a useful record for detecting the effects of experimental changes in BMPs. We also sampled small streams draining several farms within each watershed and directly on farms where BMPs were implemented. Three of the watersheds were experimental, with added BMPs, and one was a control with no additional BMPs.

We were able to recruit ~60% of farmers from the four watersheds, largely due to our co-PI from UMD Extension. The cooperating farmers agreed to take surveys, add additional BMPs with additional funding, and allow us to sample the groundwater and surface waters on their farms. Surveys indicated that the farmers considered themselves stewards of the land, but they were somewhat unaware of local impacts on water quality and largely unaware of the consequences of leakage of agricultural N and P to downstream estuarine waters. The farmers identified the time and cost of installing BMPs as the major impediments to additional BMP implementation, and they indicated high levels of trust in information from personnel from the University of Maryland Extension and Soil/Water Conservation Districts. Least trusted were environmental groups, MD Dept of Natural Resources, and MD Dept of the Environment. The results of our surveys indicated that presenting information on water quality data did not impact farmer ratings of pollutants, but did increase their willingness to implement BMPs. The greatest impediments to additional BMPs were the time and costs of installation, interference with flexibility to change land use practices, lack of government funds for cost shares, and restrictions and requirements of government programs.

Prior to implementing any new BMPs, we monitored groundwater and ditches on cooperating farms for two years to obtain baseline data. In 2015 we began encouraging our cooperating farmers to add additional BMPs, taking advantage of available cost-share funds from USDA and the state of MD. We also successfully raised funds to pay for non-cost-shared portions of BMPs, making BMPs financially cost-free  and in some cases “time-free” (e.g., cover crops were flown directly onto the fields) for our cooperating farmers. By the end of 2018, we had doubled the number of BMPs in the three experimental watersheds by adding winter cover crops, ditch bioreactors, drainage control structures, split fertilizer applications, precision fertilizer applications (Greenseeker), and other experimental BMPs.

 Baseflow water quality at the outlet of our control watershed with no additional BMPs did not change. However, baseflow water quality is slowly improving (lower N concentrations) in two of our three experimental watersheds, but with no improvements in baseflow P. The decreasing baseflow N had started in ~2008 prior to our project, probably due to the USDA and MD cover crop programs, but was accelerated by the additional BMPs of our research project. The third experimental watershed has 72% agricultural land use, sandy soils, and is heavily irrigated; in this watershed, despite BMP additions, baseflow N concentrations have increased continuously since 2003 and during the 7 years of the project. We are still analyzing stormflow data, and integrating stormflows into watershed export, which will be the main topic of a manuscript to be developed this fall. Our research showed that additional cost-free BMPs can reduce baseflow N concentrations in some agricultural watersheds, but that areas with high agricultural land use and well-drained and irrigated soils will require additional measures to reduce losses of N and P from grain production fields.
